sentence: Cloud computing company specialist Salesforce.com (CRM) is set to report fourth quarter fiscal 2018 earnings results after the closing bell Wednesday.
Salesforce stock over the past decade has been one of the stronger growth stories in the technology, driven by its leading position in the fast-growing cloud market, which it pioneered.
But the company is not alone anymore.
Salesforce’s competitive standing in its core market is also where the likes of Microsoft (MSFT) and Oracle (ORCL) have begun to capture share.
This afternoon, investors will want to see signs that Salesforce’s growth rate can continue to accelerate.
For the quarter that ended January, Wall Street expects the San Francisco-based company to report 34 cents in earnings per share on revenue of $2.81 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when the company earned 28 cents per share on $2.29 billion in revenue.
For the full year, earnings are projected to increase 32% year over year to $1.34 per share, while revenue of $10.44 billion would mark a 24.4% rise year over year.
In the third quarter the company beat on EPS by 2 cents, while revenue rose 25% year over year to $2.68 billion.
Beyond the top- and bottom-line beat, the company showed that it can deliver in the metrics that underscores its strong cloud position.
Third quarter subscription and support revenue surged 25% year over year to $2.5 billion, while Professional services and other revenue grew 20% to $194 million.
Notably, deferred revenue, which denotes the strength of future sales, grew 24% to $4.4 billion, while un-billed deferred revenue reached $11.5 billion, up 34%.
In other words, the company is operating on all cylinders.
But mixed guidance for the just-ended quarter put the stock under pressure.
Though its revenue forecast surpassed analysts’ estimates, Salesforce guided for Q4 EPS in the range of from 32 cents to 33 cents, which was a penny below consensus.
Since then the stock, which has soared 43% over the year, has recovered, reaching a new all-time high on Tuesday at $117.61.
Given that Salesforce has topped or matched the Street’s earnings estimates in fourteen straight quarters, investors have taken it for granted that another beat is in the works.
The question, as with Q3, will be about guidance.
Will Salesforce issue an outlook that is much stronger for 2018?
Likewise, there will be a focus placed on the company’s expenses to see the extent to which its overseas investments will impact the bottom line — not just for this quarter, but for the rest of 2018.
About three-quarters of the company’s revenue now comes from the Americas.
The company’s ability to capture more growth overseas will assuage investors’ uneasiness about guidance.
That said, while these shares aren’t cheap at 67 times forward estimates, compared to a P/E of 18 for the S&P 500 index, you would be hard-pressed to find a hotter software company on the market.
